Definition: Alopecia is a condition that causes hair loss, which can occur in patches or throughout the scalp.
Causes: Autoimmune disorders, genetics, and hormonal changes.
Symptoms: Hair loss in patches, thinning hair, and bald spots.
Diagnosis: Physical examination and sometimes scalp biopsy.
Treatment: Topical treatments, corticosteroids, and hair restoration techniques.

Definition: Hammer toe is a deformity that causes the toe to bend downward at the middle joint.
Causes: Improper footwear, muscle imbalance, and arthritis.
Symptoms: Pain, corns, and difficulty moving the toe.
Treatment: Footwear modifications, splints, and surgery in severe cases.

Definition: A hamstring injury is a strain or tear of the hamstring muscles at the back of the thigh.
Causes: Overstretching, sudden movements, and inadequate warm-up.
Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and bruising in the back of the thigh.
Treatment: Rest, ice, compression, and physical therapy.

Definition: Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder that attacks the thyroid gland, leading to hypothyroidism.
Causes: Autoimmune response and genetic predisposition.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, and sensitivity to cold.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring thyroid hormone levels and antibodies.
Treatment: Thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

Definition: Head and neck lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system in the head and neck region.
Alternative Names: Lymphoma of the head and neck
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve immune system factors.
Symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, sore throat, and unexplained weight loss.
Diagnosis: Biopsy, imaging studies, and blood tests.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Osteoma is a benign bone tumor that can occur in the head and neck region.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may be related to genetic factors.
Symptoms: Asymptomatic in many cases, but may cause pain or pressure.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies such as X-rays or CT scans.
Treatment: Surgical removal if symptomatic.

Definition: A headache is a pain or discomfort in the head, scalp, or neck.
Causes: Tension, migraines, sinus issues, and other medical conditions.
Symptoms: Pain, throbbing, and sensitivity to light or sound.
Treatment: Pain relievers, lifestyle changes, and preventive medications.

Definition: Hearing loss is a partial or total inability to hear.
Causes: Aging, noise exposure, infections, and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Difficulty understanding speech, muffled sounds, and ringing in the ears.
Treatment: Hearing aids, cochlear implants, and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: A heart attack occurs when blood flow to a part of the heart is blocked, causing damage to the heart muscle.
Causes: Coronary artery disease, blood clots, and plaque buildup.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, and nausea.
Diagnosis: Electrocardiogram (ECG), blood tests, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Medications, angioplasty, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Heart block is a condition where the electrical signals in the heart are delayed or blocked.
Causes: Heart disease, certain medications, and congenital conditions.
Symptoms: Fatigue, dizziness, and fainting.
Treatment: Monitoring, medications, and pacemaker implantation in severe cases.

Definition: Heart disease in women refers to various cardiovascular conditions that affect women.
Causes: Risk factors include high blood pressure, diabetes, and smoking.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue.
Diagnosis: Medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Heart failure is a condition where the heart cannot pump enough blood to meet the body's needs.
Causes: Coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, and previous heart attacks.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs.
Diagnosis: Physical examination, imaging studies, and blood tests.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A heart murmur is an unusual sound heard during a heartbeat, often indicating turbulent blood flow.
Causes: Heart valve issues, congenital heart defects, and anemia.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic, but may indicate underlying heart problems.
Treatment: Depends on the underlying cause; may include monitoring or surgery.

Definition: Heartburn is a burning sensation in the chest caused by acid reflux.
Causes: Weak lower esophageal sphincter, obesity, and certain foods.
Symptoms: Burning sensation in the chest, regurgitation, and difficulty swallowing.
Treatment: Antacids, lifestyle changes, and medications to reduce acid.

Definition: Hemangiomas are benign tumors made up of blood vessels, often appearing as red or purple marks on the skin.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Red or purple lesions on the skin, often raised.
Diagnosis: Physical examination and imaging studies if deeper.
Treatment: Often not needed, but may include medications or surgery in some cases.

Definition: Hemophilia is a genetic disorder that impairs the body's ability to make blood clots.
Causes: Genetic mutations affecting clotting factors.
Symptoms: Excessive bleeding, easy bruising, and joint pain.
Treatment: Replacement therapy for missing clotting factors and supportive care.

Definition: Hemorrhoids are swollen veins in the lower rectum and anus.
Causes: Straining during bowel movements, pregnancy, and obesity.
Symptoms: Pain, itching, and bleeding during bowel movements.
Diagnosis: Physical examination and sometimes imaging studies.
Treatment: Dietary changes, topical treatments, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Henoch–Schönlein purpura is a small-vessel vasculitis that causes inflammation and bleeding in the small blood vessels.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but often follows infections.
Symptoms: Purplish rash, joint pain, and abdominal pain.
Treatment: Supportive care and medications to manage symptoms.

Definition: Hepatitis is an inflammation of the liver, which can be caused by viruses, alcohol, or toxins.
Causes: Viral infections, alcohol abuse, and autoimmune diseases.
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
Treatment: Depends on the cause; may include antiviral medications and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Hepatitis B is a viral infection that attacks the liver and can cause both acute and chronic diseases.
Causes: Infection with the hepatitis B virus.
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
Treatment: Antiviral medications and monitoring for liver damage.

Definition: Hepatitis C is a viral infection that primarily affects the liver.
Causes: Infection with the hepatitis C virus.
Symptoms: Fatigue, jaundice, and abdominal pain.
Treatment: Antiviral medications and monitoring for liver damage.

Definition: HER2 positive breast cancer is a type of breast cancer that has a growth-promoting protein on the outside of the cancer cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations and overexpression of the HER2 gene.
Symptoms: Lump in the breast, changes in breast shape, and discharge.
Treatment: Targeted therapies, chemotherapy, and surgery.

Definition: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia is a genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation.
Causes: Genetic mutations affecting blood vessel formation.
Symptoms: Nosebleeds, skin lesions, and gastrointestinal bleeding.
Treatment: Management of symptoms and sometimes surgical interventions.

Definition: A herniated disc occurs when the soft material inside a spinal disc pushes out through a tear in the outer layer.
Causes: Aging, injury, and repetitive strain.
Symptoms: Pain, numbness, and weakness in the affected area.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A hiatal hernia occurs when part of the stomach pushes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity.
Causes: Increased pressure in the abdomen, obesity, and age.
Symptoms: Heartburn, regurgitation, and chest pain.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Hypercholesterolemia is a condition characterized by high levels of cholesterol in the blood.
Causes: Diet, genetics, and certain medical conditions.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic but can lead to heart disease.
Treatment: Dietary changes, medications, and lifestyle modifications.

Definition: Hip dysplasia is a condition where the hip joint is improperly formed, leading to instability.
Causes: Genetic factors and positioning in the womb.
Symptoms: Hip pain, limping, and reduced range of motion.
Treatment: Bracing, physical therapy, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Hip impingement occurs when the hip joint is not properly shaped, causing pain and limited movement.
Causes: Genetic factors and repetitive hip movements.
Symptoms: Hip pain, stiffness, and a clicking sensation.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: A hip labral tear is an injury to the cartilage that surrounds the hip joint.
Causes: Injury, hip impingement, and repetitive motions.
Symptoms: Hip pain, stiffness, and a clicking sensation.
Treatment: Physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Hip pain can arise from various conditions affecting the hip joint and surrounding structures.
Causes: Arthritis, injuries, and bursitis.
Symptoms: Pain in the hip joint, groin, or outer thigh.
Treatment: Rest, physical therapy, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Histiocytosis is a group of disorders characterized by an overproduction of histiocytes, a type of immune cell.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve genetic factors.
Symptoms: Varies widely; may include skin lesions, bone pain, and organ dysfunction.
Treatment: Depends on the type; may include chemotherapy and supportive care.

Definition: HIV (Human Immunodeficiency Virus) is a virus that attacks the immune system, leading to AIDS.
Causes: Transmission through blood, sexual contact, and from mother to child.
Symptoms: Flu-like symptoms initially, followed by a prolonged asymptomatic period.
Diagnosis: Blood tests to detect HIV antibodies or viral load.
Treatment: Antiretroviral therapy (ART) to manage the virus.

Definition: Hives are raised, itchy welts on the skin that can vary in size and shape.
Causes: Allergic reactions, stress, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Itching, redness, and swelling.
Treatment: Antihistamines and avoiding triggers.

Definition: Hodgkin lymphoma is a type of cancer that originates in the lymphatic system.
Causes: Exact cause is unknown, but may involve viral infections and genetic factors.
Symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes, fever, and night sweats.
Treatment: Chemotherapy, radiation therapy, and sometimes stem cell transplant.

Definition: HR+ breast cancer is a type of breast cancer that has hormone receptors on the cancer cells.
Causes: Genetic mutations and hormonal factors.
Symptoms: Lump in the breast, changes in breast shape, and discharge.
Diagnosis: Mammography, biopsy, and hormone receptor testing.
Treatment: Hormonal therapies, chemotherapy, and surgery.

Definition: Huntington's disease is a genetic disorder that causes the progressive breakdown of nerve cells in the brain.
Causes: Genetic mutation in the HTT gene.
Symptoms: Movement disorders, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.
Treatment: Supportive care and medications to manage symptoms.

Definition: Hydrocephalus is a condition characterized by an accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain.
Causes: Congenital defects, tumors, and infections.
Symptoms: Headache, nausea, and cognitive difficulties.
Diagnosis: Imaging studies such as MRI or CT scans.
Treatment: Surgical placement of a shunt to drain excess fluid.

Definition: Hyperaldosteronism is a condition characterized by excessive production of aldosterone, a hormone that regulates sodium and potassium levels.
Causes: Adrenal tumors or hyperplasia.
Symptoms: High blood pressure, muscle weakness, and frequent urination.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring aldosterone and renin levels.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Hypercalcemia is a condition characterized by elevated levels of calcium in the blood.
Causes: Hyperparathyroidism, cancer, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, confusion, and kidney stones.
Treatment: Hydration, medications, and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by overactivity of the parathyroid glands, leading to excess parathyroid hormone.
Causes: Benign tumors, genetic factors, and vitamin D deficiency.
Symptoms: Fatigue, kidney stones, and bone pain.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring calcium and parathyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Surgery, medications, and monitoring.

Definition: Hypertension is a condition characterized by consistently elevated blood pressure.
Causes: Genetics, poor diet, lack of exercise, and stress.
Symptoms: Often asymptomatic but can lead to headaches and dizziness.
Diagnosis: Blood pressure measurements and medical history.
Treatment: Lifestyle changes and medications.

Definition: Hypertensive heart disease refers to heart problems caused by high blood pressure.
Causes: Chronic high blood pressure leading to heart muscle thickening.
Symptoms: Chest pain, shortness of breath, and fatigue.
Diagnosis: Blood pressure measurements, imaging studies, and ECG.
Treatment: Medications to lower blood pressure and lifestyle changes.

Definition: Hyperthyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland produces too much thyroid hormone.
Causes: Graves' disease, thyroid nodules, and excessive iodine intake.
Symptoms: Weight loss, rapid heartbeat, and anxiety.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring thyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Antithyroid medications, radioactive iodine, and surgery.

Definition: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy is a condition where the heart muscle becomes abnormally thick.
Causes: Genetic mutations and family history.
Symptoms: Shortness of breath, chest pain, and palpitations.
Treatment: Medications, lifestyle changes, and sometimes surgery.

Definition: Hypogonadism is a condition characterized by low hormone production from the gonads.
Alternative Names: Low testosterone in men, low estrogen in women
Causes: Genetic factors, injury, and certain medical conditions.
Symptoms: Fatigue, decreased libido, and infertility.
Treatment: Hormone replacement therapy and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is a condition where the body does not produce enough gonadotropins, leading to low sex hormone levels.
Causes: Pituitary gland disorders, genetic conditions, and stress.
Symptoms: Delayed puberty, infertility, and decreased libido.
Treatment: Hormone replacement therapy and addressing underlying causes.

Definition: Hypoparathyroidism is a condition characterized by low levels of parathyroid hormone.
Causes: Surgical removal of the parathyroid glands, autoimmune disorders.
Symptoms: Muscle cramps, tingling, and seizures.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring calcium and parathyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Calcium and vitamin D supplements.

Definition: Hypothermia is a medical emergency that occurs when the body loses heat faster than it can produce it.
Causes: Prolonged exposure to cold temperatures.
Symptoms: Shivering, confusion, and fatigue.
Treatment: Rewarming techniques and supportive care.

Definition: Hypothyroidism is a condition where the thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormones.
Causes: Hashimoto's thyroiditis, iodine deficiency, and certain medications.
Symptoms: Fatigue, weight gain, and sensitivity to cold.
Diagnosis: Blood tests measuring thyroid hormone levels.
Treatment: Thyroid hormone replacement therapy.
